clinical_study.brief_title: Symptoms Comparison: Vortek Double-J Stents vs Polaris Loop Stents After RIRS
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison Between Symptoms Related to Positioning a Hydrophilic Vortek Double J and a Polaris Loop Ureteral Stent at the End of RIRS With Ureteral Sheath for Renal Calculi

lead_sponsor.agency: Azienda Ospedaliera Città della Salute e della Scienza di Torino

clinical_study.source: Azienda Ospedaliera Città della Salute e della Scienza di Torino

brief_summary.textblock:
JJ ureteral stents are often positioned at the end of a ureteroscopy and often cause important comorbidities. Indeed, up to 80% of the patients complain a deterioration of the quality of life. In order to reducing the symptoms to the minimum, the producing companies developed different types of stents, hypothetically thinking that modifications in materials and designs might reduce patients' discomfort.
Talking about materials, most ureteral stents are made up of polymers, especially polyurethane and its derivatives. Classic ureteral stents have a proximal J and a distal J as anchors respectively in the kidney and in the bladder. Different types of ureteral stents have been proposed along the years in order to improving the efficacy and reducing the complications. As long as the bladder J has been identified as one of the determining factors of the low tolerance to stents, other shapes and designs were proposed along the years to reduce the impact of the distal end. In particular, one type of stent was designed by substituting the distal J with a double loop in order to reducing the bladder impact.
Literature related to efficacy of bladder double loop in reducing symptoms caused by stent positioning and in improving comfort in comparison with a traditional hydrophilic Vortek JJ are extremely limited.
From 2008 an Italian version of USSQ is at disposal in order to evaluating with a standard method the symptoms reported by patients after ureteral stent positioning.
Aim of this study study is comparing prospectively in a randomized way symptoms of patients with bladder double loop stent and symptoms of patients with traditional hydrophilic Vortek JJ by submitting USSQ to the patients who undergo a RIRS with ureteral sheath and laser lithotripsy for renal lithiasis.

primary_outcome.description: Evaluation of significant differences in symptoms causead by the two types of uretherale stents using USSQ questionnaire

secondary_outcome.description: Evaluation of significant differences in symptoms caused by the two types of ureteral stents using USSQ questionnaire
Evaluation of significant differences in symptoms caused by the two types of ureteral stents using USSQ questionnaire
Evaluation of the easiness at positioning the two types of stent: number of successes and subjective feeling of the surgeon
Evaluation of the complications related to each type of stent: uneasy removal, encrustation, need of access to ER, extra medical assistance or antidolorific meds or antibiotics

arm_group.description: Vortek double-J stent positioning after RIRS. USSQ questionnaire administration.
Polaris Loop ureteral stent positioning after RIRS. USSQ questionnaire administration.

intervention.description: USSQ symptoms questionnaire administration after Vortek double-J stent versus Polaris Loop stent

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients affected by ureteral lithiasis treated with RIRS and laser lithotripsy with positive outcome, without significant stone fragments or periprocedural complications
- signature on informed consent
- WHO PS 0-2
Exclusion Criteria:
- any unsatisfied inclusion criteria
- significant stone fragments at the end of the procedure
- complicated ureteroscopy (perforation, stenosis or important ureteral wall damage)
- urinary tract infections
- neurological bladder
- patients younger than 18 yo or over 85

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Azienda Ospedaliera Città della Salute e della Scienza di Torino
